body: I'm amazed  this did not come up earlier.

issue.title: Docs update

repository.name: ralph
repository.description: Ralph is the CMDB / Asset Management system for data center and back office hardware.

issue.body:
First of all docs automatically build should be fixed: https://readthedocs.org/projects/ralph-ng/builds/3660852/ (it's probably related to https://github.com/mitsuhiko/click/issues/494 - if yes don't know if we can change it ourself).

(sub)sections that need update:
- [ ] configuration - list all available (Ralph) config options. Move here `LDAP Authentication` from `Installation` as well.
- [x] move current `Transitions` content to `Developer guide` - Transitions for `User guide` should describe transitions from user point of view (how to configure transition, select actions, actions could have some fields required, transition history etc)
- [ ] API - list all available resources. consider apiary / swagger (http://blog.apiary.io/2016/01/18/We-ve-got-Swagger/)
- [x] describe main modules (BO, DC, Licences, Supports). 
- [x] describe DC View
- [x] describe asset lifecycle
- [x] describe reports
- [ ] describe some major functions as bulk add, bulk edit, import/export
- [ ] describe inkpy (how to configure it with RQ)
- [ ] describe permissions mechanism (per object, per field etc)

body:
I encountered this error when setting up a LaunchDaemon to run a script built with click.  This fix merely defers the problem to some other code.  With this changed, the Traceback changes to:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/JohnJ/Source/project/myscript.py", line 960, in <module>
    cli()
  File "/Users/JohnJ/Source/project/env3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/click/core.py", line 716, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/JohnJ/Source/project/env3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/click/core.py", line 675, in main
    _verify_python3_env()
  File "/Users/JohnJ/Source/project/env3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/click/_unicodefun.py", line 119, in _verify_python3_env
    'mitigation steps.' + extra)
RuntimeError: Click will abort further execution because Python 3 was configured to use ASCII as encoding for the environment.  Either run this under Python 2 or consult http://click.pocoo.org/python3/ for mitigation steps.

This system lists a couple of UTF-8 supporting locales that
you can pick from.  The following suitable locales where
discovered: af_ZA.UTF-8, am_ET.UTF-8, be_BY.UTF-8, bg_BG.UTF-8, ca_ES.UTF-8, cs_CZ.UTF-8, da_DK.UTF-8, de_AT.UTF-8, de_CH.UTF-8, de_DE.UTF-8, el_GR.UTF-8, en_AU.UTF-8, en_CA.UTF-8, en_GB.UTF-8, en_IE.UTF-8, en_NZ.UTF-8, en_US.UTF-8, es_ES.UTF-8, et_EE.UTF-8, eu_ES.UTF-8, fi_FI.UTF-8, fr_BE.UTF-8, fr_CA.UTF-8, fr_CH.UTF-8, fr_FR.UTF-8, he_IL.UTF-8, hr_HR.UTF-8, hu_HU.UTF-8, hy_AM.UTF-8, is_IS.UTF-8, it_CH.UTF-8, it_IT.UTF-8, ja_JP.UTF-8, kk_KZ.UTF-8, ko_KR.UTF-8, lt_LT.UTF-8, nl_BE.UTF-8, nl_NL.UTF-8, no_NO.UTF-8, pl_PL.UTF-8, pt_BR.UTF-8, pt_PT.UTF-8, ro_RO.UTF-8, ru_RU.UTF-8, sk_SK.UTF-8, sl_SI.UTF-8, sr_YU.UTF-8, sv_SE.UTF-8, tr_TR.UTF-8, uk_UA.UTF-8, zh_CN.UTF-8, zh_HK.UTF-8, zh_TW.UTF-8
```

I'm not sure what the correct fix for this is.  LaunchD is apparently trying to run everything in some ascii-like locale.  Although sub-optimal, this shouldn't be a very peculiar situation.

Incidentally, one way to specifically fix LaunchD is to add a unicode LANG environment variable to the job definition, like so:

```
    <key>EnvironmentVariables</key>
    <dict>
        <key>LANG</key>
        <string>en_US.UTF-8</string>
    </dict>
```

OS X doesn't set up the locale properly anywhere; it's not just a launchd problem.  Terminal emulators are responsible for setting up a UTF-8 locale.  Both Terminal.app and iTerm2 have a setting for it.  It's a very strange situation.  If anything, it's an OS X bug for not setting up the locale, or a Python 3 bug for believing OS X about the ASCII locale.

issue.title: Attempt to use an available locale

repository.name: click
repository.description: Python composable command line interface toolkit

issue.body:
Click can detect if usable locales are available, but only exhibits this to users via a message.
I originally came across this via untitaker/vdirsyncer#335, where there was a possible sane environment, but click was still failing.

This patch attempts to use one of those good locales. It seems to fix click failing when both `LANG` and `LC_CTYPES` are unset, with no obvious drawbacks.

I haven't added any tests (yet) because I'd like to know if this patch is acceptable, or if, in my ignorance, I've overlooked something that makes this useless. It it's acceptable, I'll add some tests (and polish it a bit).

issue.title: Won't run from cron
issue.body:
Hej there,

Not sure what's going wrong here, vdirsyncer runs fine from a terminal, but when I put it in cron it dies like this:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/vdirsyncer", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/click/core.py", line 716, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/click/core.py", line 675, in main
    _verify_python3_env()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/click/_unicodefun.py", line 69, in _verify_python3_env
    if locale.lower().endswith(('.utf-8', '.utf8')):
TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'
```

Vdirsyncer was installed through pip3 (systemwide).

issue.title: Problem with encoding of locale string

repository.name: click
repository.description: Python composable command line interface toolkit

issue.body:
Hi there.  I am running a click-based python command line utility over an SSH connection using paramiko, and I see this error:

```
  File "/Users/broxton/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/click/core.py", line 716, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/broxton/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/click/core.py", line 675, in main
    _verify_python3_env()
  File "/Users/broxton/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/click/_unicodefun.py", line 69, in _verify_python3_env
    print(locale.lower().endswith(('utf-8', '.utf8')))
TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'
```

This is on a machine running Mac OS 10.11 and Anaconda Python 3.5.

It appears that `click` is calling `locale -a` through a sub-process, and the result is being returned as a byte string rather than a Python string.  The call to `.endswith()` fails because Python refuses to compare a bytes-like object to the strings in the tuple: `('utf-8', '.utf8')`  This error does not occur when I run the command through my local shell, rather than remotely over the ssh connection.  

Coercing the locale string returned by `subprocess()` allows click to proceed further to the more informative error message:

```
RuntimeError: Click will abort further execution because Python 3 was configured to use ASCII as encoding for the environment.  Either run this under Python 2 or consult http://click.pocoo.org/python3/ for mitigation steps.
```

The first error seems to mask the second, so I would recommend adding a tiny bit of type coercion here from a byte to a string type here so that this code works in either case and the user can then encounter the helpful `RuntimeErrror` message that leads them to correct their locale issue.

issue.title: Can't run mutmut
issue.body:
I have this error.

command:
`mutmut run --paths-to-mutate=$PROJECT --tests-dir=$TESTS_DIR`

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/mutmut", line 5, in <module>

    _verify_python3_env()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/click/_unicodefun.py", line 69, in _verify_python3_env
    if locale.lower().endswith(('.utf-8', '.utf8')):
TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'


```
